awd_titl_txt: Familiarity and Meaning in Visual Working Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
Visual working memory allows people to briefly hold visual information in awareness. Researchers investigating this memory system have found that people are capable of holding in mind very few objects at a time, and that this number is related to many different factors. The current research focuses on how factors such as background knowledge, familiarity and meaning affect visual working memory, as measured by the number of objects that are held. This work is expected to improve our understanding of visual skills such as those involved in driving and other complex tasks that require remembering and monitoring multiple objects. It is also expected that the work will inform the design of artificial displays and user interfaces.

The current research aims to broadly understand how the working memory system is affected by background knowledge, familiarity and meaningfulness. In order to isolate the visual working memory system -- and separate it from other memory systems, like long-term memory -- a large amount of research focuses on working memory for simple shapes or colors. Such research allows us to isolate the contributions of visual working memory, but is not indicative of how we use our memory in the real world. This project will focus on understanding both the cognitive and neural mechanisms of visual working memory for meaningful objects more like those we encounter in our everyday life. In particular, we will use both behavioral manipulations designed to isolate working memory and a neural marker of brain activity measured with electroencephalography to track how much is held in visual working memory to measure memory capacity for meaningful objects. We will also employ a cognitive training paradigm designed to improve visual working memory capacity by creating new meaningful connections between objects. Overall, the goal of the research is to better understand how to measure and improve visual working memory for realistic and meaningful objects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Visual working memory allows people to hold visual information in an active state, in order to allow them to perform tasks that depend on visual knowledge. Previous research has shown that this memory system is highly limited, as people are able to hold only a few objects in mind accurately. In addition, it  has been shown that how much people can hold  in working memory is a major constraint on cognition in general, as working memory capacity is related to fluid intelligence, academic achievement and other important abilities. In the current project, we examined how this memory system is used in more realistic situations, with familiar objects.


The vast majority of previous research on visual working memory capacity has asked people to remember only very simple visual objects (like colored circles or lines), which helps ensure that people cannot use their existing knowledge of everyday objects and events to help their performance. Such research allows us to isolate the contributions of visual working memory, but is not indicative of how we use our memory in the real world. The current project enhanced the understanding of visual working memory in more realistic situations than have traditionally been studied in cognitive psychology and cognitive neuroscience by focusing on the cognitive and neural basis of how we remember familiar, everyday objects.


In particular, we used both behavioral manipulations designed to isolate working memory and a neural marker of brain activity measured with electroencephalography to track how much information is held in visual working memory when people are remembering meaningful everyday objects. Among our most important findings was that working memory capacity is larger for meaningful objects relative to visually-identical objects that are not perceived as meaningful, suggesting that there is no single, fixed working memory capacity. Instead, this project found that how accurately we can remember information in working memory depends on how meaningful the information to be remembered is, as well as the exact way it is presented (e.g., whether we focus on one item at a time or try to apprehend many at once). This project also found that meaningful, real-world objects are not stored all together in working memory as a single representation. Instead, different features of these objects are often forgotten separately (e.g., people very often remember you saw a blue mug but not whether it was full or empty, rather than remembering both features). We also examined how training enhances working memory. We found that perceptual expertise, like the kind of repeated training radiologists receive in finding abnormalities in medical images, can enhance working memory capacity specifically for abnormal images, likely by making these images more distinctive for expert radiologists than for novices. Overall, we found that when remembering images of real-world objects,  working memory is flexible and less fixed, which contrasts with previous work that had shown a relatively fixed and inflexible memory system when using primarily simplified visual objects (like colored circles or oriented lines). These results open new questions about the relationship between visual working memory capacity and other cognitive abilities, like fluid intelligence.


The project also involved training undergraduate and graduate students on electrophysiology techniques and computational skills, programming experiments, stimulus preparation, as well as data analysis, manuscript preparation, and presentation skills, including several members of underrepresented groups. It also included the dissemination of research to the scientific community and to the public at large through outreach.


Last Modified: 01/31/2023
Modified by: Timothy Brady
